{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Marcelo Claure | image = Marcelo-claure.jpg | image_size = | caption = Marcelo Claure | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1970|12|9}} | birth_place = [[La Paz]], Bolivia | residence =[[Kansas City]], [[Kansas]] | nationality =[[Bolivian American]] | alma_mater =[[Bentley University]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]]) | occupation = Executive Chairman of [[Sprint Corporation]], COO of [[Softbank Group]] | spouse =Jordan Engard }}
'''Marcelo Claure''' is a Bolivian-American businessman and executive chairman and former CEO of [[Sprint Corporation]]. He was succeeded in the role of CEO by industry veteran, [[Michel Combes]]. He also serves as COO of [[SoftBank Group]]. He is also a wireless industry distribution entrepreneur and co-founder of [[Brightstar Corporation|Brightstar Corp.]]<ref>{{cite web |title= About Brightstar – Corporate Governance/Leadership Team |url= http://www.brightstarcorp.com/about/corporate-governance/leadership-team |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121102175322/http://www.brightstarcorp.com/about/corporate-governance/leadership-team |archivedate= November 2, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Since its founding in 1997, Brightstar has grown into an enterprise with $10.5 billion in gross revenue, with local presence in approximately 50 countries, on six continents. On August 5, 2014, he was selected to replace [[Daniel Hesse|Dan Hesse]] as CEO of [[Sprint Corporation]] (Effective August 11, 2014). The announcement was made on August 6, 2014, coinciding with Bolivia's independence day.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Knutson|first1=Ryan|last2=Mattioli|first2=Dana|title=Sprint Abandons Pursuit of T-Mobile, Replaces CEO|url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/sprint-abandoning-pursuit-of-t-mobile-1407279448?mod=WSJ_hp_LEFTTopStories|accessdate=August 6, 2014|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=August 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= Brightstar Media Page |url= http://www.brightstarcorp.com/media |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121101174359/http://www.brightstarcorp.com/media |archivedate= November 1, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
==Early life and education== He spent two years living in Guatemala, his family moved to Morocco and then to the Dominican Republic before returning home to La Paz, Bolivia, where he spent most of his childhood. He attended the American Cooperative School in La Paz, graduating in 1989. Later that year, he left La Paz to attend what was then the [[University of Massachusetts Lowell|University of Lowell]], in [[Lowell, Massachusetts]]. He subsequently transferred to [[Bentley University]], in [[Waltham, Massachusetts]], graduating in 1993 with a [[Bachelor of Science]] in Economics and Finance.<ref>{{cite web |title= Hispanic Business, June 2007. "Hispanic Business, Shining Through" Derek Reveron |url= http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2007/5/31/shining_through.htm |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140222042353/http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2007/5/31/shining_through.htm |archivedate= February 22, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==Business career== After graduation, Claure returned to La Paz and joined the Bolivian Football Federation as International Marketing Manager.
In 1995, he returned to the United States and bought USA Wireless, a cellular retailer. He grew and expanded the company before selling it one year later.<ref name="auto">{{cite web |title= Hispanic Business, June 2007 ."Hispanic Business, Shining Through" Derek Reveron |url= http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2007/5/31/shining_through.htm |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140222042353/http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2007/5/31/shining_through.htm |archivedate= February 22, 2014 |df= }}</ref> In 1996, Claure became President of Small World Communications, a [[California]]-based communications and distribution company.<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|title= EDGAR Online |url=http://sec.edgar-online.com/brightstar-corp/s-1a-securities-registration-statement/2004/09/20/Section25.aspx }}</ref> He led the company for two years before re-locating to Florida to start [[Brightstar Corporation|Brightstar]] in 1997.<ref name="auto"/>
==Brightstar== [[Brightstar Corporation|Brightstar]] was founded in Miami in 1997, as a distributor and service provider to the wireless industry with a focus on the Latin American market. The company opened offices in Bolivia, Brazil, Paraguay and the Caribbean. In 2000, the company entered distribution agreement with Motorola for all of Latin America. This was followed by the launch of subsidiaries in Argentina, Uruguay, Venezuela, Ecuador, Peru and El Salvador. A US Brightstar subsidiary opened in 2001, based in Chicago, and later expanded into Asia, followed by Europe, the Middle East and Africa.
Brightstar operates in approximately 50 countries and all six continents around the globe. ''Forbes Magazine'' recognized it as one of the largest privately held companies in the US, listing it 55th in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title= Forbes America's Largest Private Companies 2013|url=https://www.forbes.com/largest-private-companies/#page:6_sort:0_direction:asc_search: }}</ref> ''Inc. Magazine'' identified Brightstar as one of the fastest-growing companies in the U.S., placing it sixth in its annual Inc. 500/5000 listing in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title= Inc. 5000 |url= http://www.inc.com/inc5000/profile/brightstar }}</ref> It has also been recognized by HispanicBusiness.com as the largest Hispanic-owned business in the U.S. in 2007, 2008, 2009, 2011, 2012 and 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title= Hispanic Business Top 500 Hispanic Businesses|url= http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/research/500/list.asp?ListYear=2012|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121001231304/http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/research/500/list.asp?listyear=2012|archivedate= October 1, 2012|df= }}</ref>
On October 18, 2013, Brightstar Corp. ("Brightstar") and SOFTBANK CORP. ("SoftBank") (TSE: 9984) announced a definitive agreement for SoftBank to invest $1.26 billion in Brightstar. (The transaction closed in January 2014.)
In December 2013, Brightstar announced plans to acquire 20:20 Mobile in Europe. The transaction closed in February 2014 and Brightstar now owns facilities in the UK, Spain, Hungary, Portugal, Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden, providing products and services across 13 European countries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brightstar Completes Acquisition of 20:20 Mobile Group in Europe|url=http://www.brightstar.com/media/press-releases/brightstar-completes-acquisition-of-2020-mobile-group-in-europe}}</ref>
Also, in February 2014, Brightstar announced plans to acquire the Commerce & Services Division of [[SoftBank Group]]. The transaction closed in April 2014 and as a result Brightstar became the primary global distributor for the SoftBank Selection brand mobile products, which feature more than 765 mobile accessories. The new company is expected to grow Brightstar’s presence in Japan and increase the company’s revenues by $3 billion on an annualized basis.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brightstar Expands Business with Acquisition of the Commerce & Services Division of SoftBank Corp.|url=http://www.brightstar.com/media/press-releases/brightstar-expands-business-with-acquisition-of-the-commerce-services-divis}}</ref>
==Sprint== Claure became [[Sprint Corporation]] President and CEO on Aug. 11, 2014, and has served on the Sprint board of directors since January 2014. He is also a member of the board of directors of SoftBank Group, as well as the board of [[Arm]], a leading chip technology developer.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sprint Elevates Marcelo Claure To Executive Chairman And Appoints Michel Combes as CEO|url=http://newsroom.sprint.com/sprint-elevates-marcelo-claure-to-executive-chairman-and-appoints-michel-combes-as-ceo.htm}}</ref>
==Other== Claure is chairman of [[CTIA (organization)|CTIA]].<ref>https://www.ctia.org/</ref>
==Football and Club Bolivar== In 2008, Claure created BAISA (Bolivar Administracion, Inversiones y Servicios Asociados, S.R.L.), to acquire and operate Club Bolivar, the most popular soccer Club in Bolivia and the ninth-ranked team in Latin America.<ref>{{cite web|title="Bolívar Administración e Inversiones S.A. BAISA September 2008|url=http://www.bolivar.com.bo/baisa_detalle.php?cbo=101 }}</ref>
Claure has also previously served on [[FIFA]]'s (Federation Internationale de Football Association's) Committee for Fair Play and Social Responsibility.<ref>{{cite web|title="World Economic Forum: Marcelo Claure |url=https://www.weforum.org/people/marcelo-claure }}</ref>
In 2018, Claure - along with [[David Beckham]] (global soccer icon); [[Simon Fuller]] (entertainment entrepreneur and manager); Jorge and Jose Mas (leaders of Miami-based telecom and construction giant MasTec); and [[Masayoshi Son]] (visionary technologist and founder and CEO of SoftBank Group) – were awarded a Major League Franchise for Miami, Florida. MLS Commissioner Don Garber announced the expansion team on January 29 in a ceremony at The Arsht Center. The event was transmitted on live TV and attended by over 1700 people including athletes, fans, celebrities, local and international business leaders, political figures and members of the national and international media. <ref>{{cite web|title="Miami's Day Finally Comes For David Beckham, Partners And Fans As MLS Names 25th Team|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/bobbymcmahon/2018/01/29/miamis-day-finally-comes-for-david-beckham-partners-and-fans-as-mls-name-its-25th-team/#1489d7cd4fa6 }}</ref>
Miami’s new futbol team will play in a privately-financed, 25,000-seat state-of-the-art stadium in downtown Miami. The stadium will be designed by Populous and is expected to be built by 2021. <ref>{{cite web|title="Beckham’s Miami soccer team has been a dream for years. The reality may be days away. |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/sports/mls/article194653114.html }}</ref>
==Awards and recognition== [[World Economic Forum]] (WEF) [[Young Global Leader]].<ref>{{cite web|title= The World Economic Forum |url=http://www.weforum.org}}</ref> [[Ernst & Young]] Entrepreneur of the Year Award and lifetime member of Ernst & Young's Entrepreneur of the Year Hall of Fame.<ref name="auto1"/> Hispanic Businessman of the Year by the [[United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce]]. Global Telecoms Business "Forty Under Forty" Leaders;<ref>{{cite web|title= Global Telecoms Business 'Forty Under Forty' Leaders 2010|url=http://www.globaltelecomsbusiness.com/Article/2455824/Global-Telecoms-Business-40-under-40-for-2010.html }}</ref> ''Hispanic Business Magazine'', Entrepreneur of the Year;<ref>{{cite web|title= Hispanic Business Magazine|url= http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2003/11/22/brightstar_founder_chosen_hispanic_entrepreneur_of.htm|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130125082332/http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/2003/11/22/brightstar_founder_chosen_hispanic_entrepreneur_of.htm|archivedate= January 25, 2013|df= }}</ref> ''[[Hispanic Magazine]]'', Top Hispanic Entrepreneurs; LISTA, CEO of the Year; [[América Economía]], Award of Excellence; ''PODER Magazine'', Top Hispanic Entrepreneur; BN Americas, Hall of Fame; ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', CEO Council Member<ref>{{cite web|title= ''Wall Street Journal'' CEO Council|url=http://ceocouncil.wsj.com/?speakers=marcelo-claure}}</ref> and The Group of Fifty (G-50) Member.
==Personal life==
Claure married in 2005 and together, the couple have three daughters. He also has two children from a previous marriage.
Claure is Catholic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/business/technology/article31927326.html|title=Marcelo’s moment: Saving Sprint is biggest challenge of Claure’s already impressive life|publisher=|accessdate=January 31, 2018}}</ref>
==Philanthropy== Together with [[Nicholas Negroponte]], he is a founding member of [[One Laptop Per Child]], an organization focused on empowering the world's poorest children through education by providing them with a rugged low-cost laptop.<ref>{{cite web|title= About the Project-People-Founding Members|url=http://one.laptop.org/about/people}}</ref>
In an effort to help high school students across the U.S. reach their full potential, Marcelo created the 1Million Project. [[Sprint Corporation]] will connect up to 1 million disadvantaged students who lack the internet access they need at home to complete their homework, search for jobs and apply to college. Each participating student will receive a device and free high-speed internet access for up to four years. <ref>{{cite web|title= Sprint Provides Free Wireless Devices and Service to 1 Million Disadvantaged Students|url=http://newsroom.sprint.com/sprint-provides-free-wireless-devices-and-service-to-1-million-disadvantaged-students.htm}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Use British English|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox comics creator | image = Maurice Dodd00.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = | birth_place = [[Metropolitan Borough of Hackney|Hackney]], [[England]] | death_place = | nationality = [[English people|English]] | cartoonist = y | write = y | art = | pencil = | ink = | edit = | publish = | letter = | color = | alias = | signature = <!-- very optional --> | signature_alt = | notable works = ''[[The Perishers]]'' | awards = | website = | subcat = English | birth_date={{Birth date|df=yes|1922|10|25}} | death_date= 31 December 2005 (aged 83) }} '''Maurice Dodd''' (25 October 1922 – 31 December 2005) was an [[English people|English]] writer and cartoonist best known for his years spent working on ''[[The Perishers]]'' [[comic strip]] published in the ''[[Daily Mirror]]''.
==Biography== Dodd was born in [[Metropolitan Borough of Hackney|Hackney]]. During the [[Second World War]] he served in the [[Royal Air Force]] as a Servicing Commando, alongside Bill Herbert. After the war Dodd was demobilised and began to study art. He then found work in advertising and, after he won a competition to write a slogan for ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', Bill Herbert, by then the cartoon editor at ''[[The Daily Mirror]]'', offered Dodd the chance to take over the writing of a comic strip he had created, ''[[The Perishers]]''. Working with the artist Dennis Collins, Dodd provided rough [[Page layout|layouts]], which Collins then drew from.
Dodd continued to work in advertising, such as on the ''[[Clunk Click Every Trip]]'' series of public information films intended to remind drivers of the benefits of wearing a [[seatbelt]]. It was while he was working on this campaign that Dodd came into contact with [[FilmFair]], a company responsible for the creation of television programmes based on [[The Wombles]] and [[Paddington Bear]]. Dodd collaborated with the company in bringing ''The Perishers'' to television. Dodd left advertising in 1980 and subsequently wrote a number of children's books.
In 1983 Collins retired, leaving Dodd to write and draw ''The Perishers'' alone until 1992, when Bill Mevin began doing all the art work for the strip. Dodd continued working on the strip until he died, from a [[brain haemorrhage]], in [[Shepperton]] on 31 December 2005.

'''Maxim Leonidovich Korobov''' (born December 3, 1957)<ref name="Council">[https://www.usrbc.org/goverment/government/russian_government_state_duma/deputies_alphabetical/9 US-Russia Business Council biography]</ref> is a Russian businessman whose investments focus on the [[oil and gas]] sector. He is the controlling shareholder of SGO Sibgasoil Investments Limited,<ref>[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=242503164 Businessweek profile]</ref> which has interests in [[Western Siberia]].
Maxim Korobov served at various times as Chairman of the Board of Directors of Swiss company Rosco S.A.; Vice President of [[Eastern Oil Company]] (EOC) and head of [[EOC Trading House]]; President of [[Tomsk Oil and Gas Company]]; and head of the oil and gas team at [[Rossiisky Kredit]] bank.<ref>[http://www.vedomosti.ru/persons/13056/%D0%9C%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%BC%20%D0%9A%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B2 Vedomosti profile]</ref>
Korobov graduated with honours from both the Military Institute of the Defence Ministry and the [[Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration|Russian Presidential Academy of State Service]]. He was also a researcher at the [[Institute of Oriental Studies of the Russian Academy of Sciences]] and taught at the Military Institute.<ref name="Council"/> He holds a PhD in political science.<ref>[http://www.bfm.ru/person/302 Business FM profile]</ref>
Maxim Korobov was elected to the [[Tomsk Oblast]] regional parliament in 1997, and served as a member of the [[State Duma]] (Russian parliament) from 1999-2011, as a member of the [[United Russia]] party.<ref name="Council"/><ref>[http://www.duma.gov.ru/structure/deputies/23840/ Russian Parliament website profile]</ref> As a member of the Duma's Committee on Power, Transport and Communications, he authored a bill proposing to end the practice of [[domestic roaming]], whereby Russian mobile network operators charge higher prices to users travelling outside their “home” regions.<ref>[http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/1641351 Kommersant newspaper: Внутрисетевому роумингу отменят плату]</ref>

'''Oriental management''' is a modern management school based on both the latest and historical theories as well as practices and rules of [[management]] inside and outside China. Although similar thoughts have been proposed in the early 1970s,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://en.cnki.com.cn/Article_en/CJFDTOTAL-GLXB200601002.htm|title=Oriental Management Theory: Its Source,Essence and Framework--《Chinese Journal of Management》2006年01期|website=en.cnki.com.cn|access-date=2018-06-20}}</ref> oriental management gained traction in the early 1990s having been launched [[Su Dongshui]]. The concept is generally based on the unique traditional culture of eastern countries, especially China, and has integrated the essence of management thoughts from both the east and the west, after decades of study.<ref>Su Dongshui, ''Oriental Management'', Shanghai: Fudan University Press, 2005.</ref>
The theoretical foundations of oriental management are ''Chinese Management'', ''Western Management,'' and ''Overseas Chinese Management''. It adopted an approach that is people-oriented, with a strong focus on "human morality," and "human behavior." The framework prioritizes learning, ideal behavior, governing, action, and harmony.<ref name=":0" />
== Utility == Aside from serving as a form of management standards for Chinese companies, oriental management can be useful for managers and organizations that encounter specific challenges involving ethics, conflict, and poor performance. Since it incorporates elements of [[Confucianism]], [[Taoism]], [[Buddhism]] and Western management theories, it is capable of creating a culture of accommodation, transformation, learning, teamwork, and respect for hierarchy, among others.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Art Of Modern Oriental Management: Applying The Chinese, Japanese And Korean Management Styles At Work|last=Ong|first=Yu Sing|publisher=World Scientific|year=2017|isbn=9789813220317|location=London|pages=26}}</ref> An understanding of oriental management can also provide people interested in doing business in China meaningful insights into the Chinese business practices and norms.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Modern Oriental Corporate Culture: A Case Collection|last=Su|first=Yong|last2=Chen|first2=Lanjian|publisher=Springer|year=2013|isbn=9783642352133|location=Heidelberg|pages=vii}}</ref>
== Scope == The research scope of oriental management is not confined to business, but extending to almost all fields of management, including individual governance, management analysis, family governance, business governance and state governance. By exercising and implementing the "Fifteen philosophical elements", including rules of governing a state, flexibility against changes, human orientedness, application of power, pragmaticism, regarding harmony as priority, attaching importance on using tools, state governance by law, embarking on a business with credit and good faith, being well planned, stratagem in decision making, subtle using of tactics, being highly efficient and uncorrupted, being industrious in making a fortune, and entelechy with reason, the highest purpose or ultimate value of oriental management is [[harmonious society]] in which everybody fulfills his comprehensive and free development. '''Rubber Technology''' is the subject dealing with the transformation of [[Natural rubber|rubbers]] or [[elastomer]]s into useful products, such as [[automobile]] [[tire]]s, [[rubber mat]]s and, exercise rubber stretching bands. The materials includes [[latex]], [[natural rubber]], [[synthetic rubber]] and other polymeric materials, such as [[thermoplastic elastomer]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Types of Rubber|url=http://www.industrialrubbergoods.com/types-of-rubber.html|publisher=Industrial Rubber Goods|accessdate=31 January 2013}}</ref> Rubber processed through such methods are components of a wide range of items.
==Vulcanization== Most rubber products are [[Vulcanization|vulcanized]], a process which involves heating with a small quantity of sulphur (or equivalent [[Cross-link|cross-linking agent]]) so as to stabilise the polymer chains, over a wide range of temperature. This discovery was made by [[Charles Goodyear]] in the 1844, but is a process restricted to polymer chains having a [[Double bond]] in the backbone.<ref>{{cite web|title=What is Vulcanized Rubber?|url=http://www.wisegeek.org/what-is-vulcanized-rubber.htm|publisher=WiseGEEK}}</ref> Such materials include [[natural rubber]] and [[polybutadiene]]. The range of materials available is much wider however, since all polymers become elastomeric above their [[Glass transition]] temperature. However, the elastomeric state is unstable because chains can slip past one another resulting in [[Creep (deformation)|creep]] or [[stress relaxation]] under static or dynamic load conditions. Chemical cross links add the stability to the network that is needed for most practical applications.{{citation needed|date=January 2013}}
[https://www.ligs.sabah.gov.my%2Findex.php%2Fcore-activities%2Fcommercial-activities%2Fprocessing-and-marketing-of-rubber%2F%3Flang%3Den&psig=AOvVaw2Ow3aVGkVMeMam9wOIkcMK&ust=1513520280297049 WORKER PROCESSING RUBBER] ==Processing of rubber== [[File:Calender machine.jpg|thumb|right|220px| Milling to soften raw rubber and mix dry ingredients into the compound]] Methods for processing rubber include [[mastication]] and various operations like mixing, [[calendering]], [[extrusion]], all processes being essential to bring crude rubber into a state suitable for shaping the final product. The former breaks down the polymer chains, and lowers their [[molecular mass]] so that [[viscosity]] is low enough for further processing. After this has been achieved, various additions can be made to the material ready for cross-linking. Rubber may be masticated on a two-roll mill or in an [[industrial mixer]], which come in different [[Industrial Mixer#Types of Mixer|types]].<ref>{{cite web|title=History of Rubber|url=http://science.howstuffworks.com/life/botany/rubber-info6.htm|publisher=HowStuffWorks}}</ref>
Rubber is first compounded with additives like sulfur, carbon black and accelerators. It is converted into a dough-like mixture which is called "compound" then milled int'''o''' sheets of desired thickness. Rubber may then be extruded or molded before being cured.

Dun & Bradstreet Reference Book of Corporate Managements: Parsippany, New Jersey</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last= Feintzeig |first= Rachel |authorlink= |title=Rock ‘n’ Role-Play: A CEO’s Burning Love For Elvis|publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=October 4, 2016 |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/rock-n-role-play-a-ceos-burning-love-for-elvis-1475172897|accessdate=}}</ref> is an American businessman, author and the CEO of [[Belfor|BELFOR Property Restoration]]. He has appeared on an [[Emmy Award|Emmy]]-nominated episode of ''[[Undercover Boss]]'' on CBS.<ref>{{Cite web|last= Larson |first=Kathryn |authorlink= |title= ‘Busted’ Undercover Boss Sheldon Yellen, Belfor CEO, Staking Claim In Detroit Real Estate |publisher=[[CBS Detroit]]|date=November 22, 2013 |url=http://detroit.cbslocal.com/2013/11/22/busted-undercover-boss-sheldon-yellen-belfor-ceo-staking-claim-in-detroit-real-estate/ |accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Leadership - Sheldon Yellen CEO|publisher=BELFOR Property Restoration website|date= |url=https://www.belfor.com/en/about-us/sheldon|accessdate=January 31, 2018}}</ref>
==Biography== Yellen was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family, the oldest of four boys.<ref name=ConnJL>{{Cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=From welfare kid to "Jewish businessman," "Undercover Boss" shares his recipe for success |publisher=[[Connecticut Jewish Ledger]]|date= |url= http://www.jewishledger.com/2011/08/from-welfare-kid-to-jewish-businessman-undercover-boss-shares-his-recipe-for-success/ |accessdate=August 31, 2011}}</ref> He was raised alone by his mother as his father became a drug addict from taking methadone to alleviate pain for his medical conditions.<ref name=ConnJL /> He attended [[Southfield-Lathrup High School]]<ref>{{Cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Fond Farewell! Former students remember Southfield-Lathrup High|publisher=[[Detroit Jewish News]]|date=June 19, 2016 |url=https://thejewishnews.com/2016/06/29/fond-farewell-former-students-remember-southfield-lathrup-high/ |accessdate=|quote=Other notable Southfield-Lathrup graduates include Quicken Loans and Cleveland Cavaliers owner Dan Gilbert, Groupon co-founder Eric Lefkofsky and Sheldon Yellen, CEO of Birmingham-based Belfor Holdings Inc.}}</ref> but dropped out to support his family (he later received his diploma at the age of 53).<ref name=Thrive>{{Cite web|last= Weiner|first=Yitzi |authorlink= |title=The Inspiring Backstory of Sheldon Yellen, CEO of BELFOR Holdings|publisher=Thrive Global|date=October 10, 2017 |url=https://journal.thriveglobal.com/the-inspiring-backstory-of-sheldon-yellen-ceo-of-belfor-holdings-6a603841e9b0 |accessdate=|quote=}}</ref> In 1985, he went to work as a salesman for his brothers-in-law's company then known as Quality Awning & Construction which also did restoration work.<ref name=Thrive /> In 1989, Yellen booked $17 million in sales in South Carolina which was devastated by [[Hurricane Hugo]], effectively doubling the company's sales.<ref name=Thrive /> He became CEO in 2001.<ref name=Thrive />
Per Yellen, in 2016 BELFOR is the world's largest disaster restoration company operating in 29 countries with more than 350 offices and employing more than 7,700 full-time employees.<ref name=Thrive />
He is a guest writer for ''[[Entrepreneur (magazine)|Entrepreneur]]'' - US edition: ''4 Ways to Ensure Your Startup Will Survive Disaster, How to Make People, Not Résumés, Your Hiring Priority, How Growing Up With Nothing Equipped Me to Run a Billion-Dollar Company''.<ref>{{Cite web|last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Sheldon Yellen |publisher=[[Entrepreneur (magazine)|Entrepreneur]]|date= |url=https://www.entrepreneur.com/author/sheldon-yellen# |accessdate=January 31, 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== At the age of 26, he married at [[Temple Israel (West Bloomfield, Michigan)|Temple Israel]] in [[West Bloomfield Township, Michigan]]; he has two sons.<ref name=ConnJL /> Although he had a [[bar mitzvah]], he did not begin to practice [[Judaism]] until he was in his mid-40s.<ref name=ConnJL />

Siuming Tsui | occupation = [[screenwriter]], [[film producer]], [[actor]], [[assistant director]], [[production management|production manager]], and [[stage combat|action choreographer]] | genre =}} '''Tsui Siu-ming''' ({{zh|c=徐小明}}; born 1953) is a [[Hong Kong]]-based [[actor]], [[screenwriter]], [[film producer]], [[assistant director]], [[production management|production manager]], and [[stage combat|action choreographer]]. ==Career== A native of [[Guangdong]], Tsui was once a recognized [[Child singer|child star]]. He had tried his hands in singing during the 1970s and 1980s with such tunes as "The New Chameleon", "Za Xiang Hu Shan Xing" and "Huei Sheng Gu Li Nian Li Qing".[http://hkmdb.com/db/people/bio.mhtml?id=3187&display_set=eng HKMDB] He also produced drama [[Serial (radio and television)|serials]] for [[Rediffusion Television]] ([[Rediffusion Television|RTV]]) such as the rating-topper "Chameleon". Tsui worked for ATV in 1998 and became CEO of [[Emperor Entertainment Group|Emperor Motion Pictures]] in the subsequent year where he was responsible for film and TV business development. {{citation needed|date=June 2009}} In March 2005, he founded [[Sundream Motion Pictures]], a [[subsidiary]] of [[pay TV]] provider [[I-CABLE Communications|I-CABLE Communications Ltd.]], producing films such as ''[[Twins Mission]]'' and ''[[Eye in the Sky (2007 film)|Eye in the Sky]]''. {{citation needed|date=June 2009}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0875291}} *[http://hkmdb.com/db/people/bio.mhtml?id=3187&display_set=eng Tsui Siu-ming biography at the Hong Kong Movie Database] * [http://www.hkcinemagic.com/en/people.asp?id=151 HK cinemagic entry] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tsui, Siuming}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Hong Kong male child actors]] [[Category:Hong Kong businesspeople]] [[Category:Hong Kong film producers]] [[Category:Hong Kong screenwriters]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Asian film producers]] [[Category:Members of the Election Committee of Hong Kong, 2007–2012]] [[Category:Members of the Election Committee of Hong Kong, 2012–2017]]

Headquartered in [[Abuja]], Nigeria's [[capital city|capital]], Unity Bank also maintains an operations base on [[Victoria Island (Nigeria)|Victoria Island]], in [[Lagos]], Nigeria's commercial capital.[http://www.unitybankng.com/unityselector.php?action=about Overview of Unity Bank Plc.] {{asof|December 2012}}, the bank's total assets were valued at about US$2.45 billion (NGN:396 billion), with shareholders' equity of approximately US$322 million (NGN:51.5 billion).[http://www.unitybankng.com/formdownloads/Annual%20report%202012.pdf Audited December 2012 Financial Report] ==History== In January 2006, nine financial institutions with expertise in [[corporate banking]], [[retail banking]], as well as [[investment banking]], came together to form Unity Bank plc.[http://www.unitybankng.com/unityselector.php?action=about Unity Bank Was Formed in 2006] ==Unity Bank Group== Unity Bank plc, is the flagship institution of the '''Unity Bank Group'''. Other members of the financial services group include the following:[http://www.unitybankng.com/unityselector.php?action=about Member Companies of the Unity Bank Group] * Unity Capital & Trust Limited * Caranda Management Services Limited * Unity Registrars Limited * Northlink Insurance Brokers Limited * Newdevco Investments & Securities Limited * UnityKapital Assurance plc * Pelican Prints Limited * Unity Bank BDC * Hexali Properties Limited ==Ownership== The shares of [[stock]] of Unity Bank plc are listed on the Nigerian Stock Exchange, where they trade under the symbol: '''UNITYBNK'''. The detailed shareholding in the bank is not publicly available at this time.{{Cite web|url=http://www.moneyhub.net/scripts/cgiip.wsc/globalone/htm/quote_and_news.r?pisharetype-id=16645|title=Unity Bank plc - UNITYBNK: stock quote, company profile & share news|last=http://www.moneyhub.net|website=www.moneyhub.net|access-date=2017-08-29}} ==Branch network== {{As of|2010|December|post=,}} Unity Bank plc maintained 242 branches across all states of Nigeria, giving it the 7th-largest branch network in the country. Another 25 branches were planned at that time.[http://www.unitybankng.com/unityselector.php?action=about Branches of Unity Bank Plc] ==See also== *[[List of banks in Nigeria]] *[[Economy of Nigeria]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.unitybankng.com Homepage of Unity Bank Nigeria] *[http://www.cenbank.org Website of Central Bank of Nigeria] {{Economy of Nigeria}} [[Category:Banks of Nigeria]] [[Category:Companies of Nigeria]] [[Category:Banks established in 2006]] [[Category:Companies established in 2006]] [[Category:Economy of Nigeria]]
